Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN:Collaborative: Documenting Fossil Marine Invertebrate Communities of the Eastern Pacific - Faunal Responses to Environmental Change over the last 66 million years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fossils provide our only direct evidence of past biodiversity and how individual organisms to ecosystems have responded to past and long-term environmental change. This project fills a major gap in the documentation of past environmental change, making available digitized data from the especially rich fossil record of the eastern Pacific marine invertebrate communities of the Cenozoic, the 66 million years that have passed since the extinction of the dinosaurs. Digitization and integration of these data will foster increased accessibility, efficient analysis to understand past change, the identification of factors involved in that change, and enable predictions for how current biodiversity may be impacted by future change. Development of virtual fieldwork experiences will assist stakeholders and educators in understanding how field data and fossil collections are used to infer past ecosystem and environmental conditions.

The data currently exist as a vast collection of fossil specimens and printed materials distributed among multiple natural history collections: this project involves 7 primary institutions, one small collection and one federal institution and will integrate this digitized specimen data with the other two ongoing fossil networks through the web portal iDigPaleo, expanding the resource for fossil invertebrate information by spanning over 500 million years. This wealth of data will provide resources not only to researchers, but will be made available to K-16 educators, government, industry, and the general public. Through the national resource (iDigBio) these data will be integrated with information on modern organisms providing the means to understand important questions on niches, environmental change, transitions in sea levels, etc. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the modern uses of natural history collections. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Eastern Pacific Invertebrate Communities of the Cenozoic (EPICC) Thematic Collections Network (TCN), a collaboration between 11 natural history museums across the US, exceeded its digitization goals, having made 1.97 million specimen records available online, photographed 203,734 specimens, and georeferenced 47,576 localities. The invertebrate fossils digitized by the TCN originate from the eastern Pacific coastline from southern Chile to Alaska and span the last 66 million years of Earth?s history, a time interval that began immediately following the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs. This effort has resulted in a more than a 27-fold increase in available data on the geographic and temporal range of marine invertebrates, exquisitely documented in the fossil record, especially molluscs, echinoderms, barnacles, corals, and crustaceans. These data will be useful for a variety of research questions including, but not limited to: (1) assessing latitudinal and temporal changes in functional diversity and food webs of marine communities; (2) quantifying the sampling biases among invertebrate and vertebrate localities; (3) reconstructing the biogeographic history of Alaskan tectonic terranes (micro-tectonic plates that slammed into Alaska); (4) documenting long-term changes in the marine invertebrate fauna (including economically important species) in relation to oceanographic and tectonic changes.

Beyond making digitally accessible this rich fossil record, which greatly facilitates cross- institutional research, education, and outreach, other significant outcomes include: (1) the training of over 150 undergraduate and graduate students in the care and use of individual museum collections, use of international biodiversity data standards, and in the value of collaboration among collections for research, education, and outreach. (2) The design and construction of online virtual field experiences (VFE) that enable students, teachers and the public to experience, via high resolution GigaPan, drone images and 3D photographs in combination with geological maps and satellite imagery, how paleontologists and geologist begin with field observations of the fossil and rocks, to the making of collections, to the drawing of inferences about past ecosystems, environments, and climates. The virtual fieldwork experiences are well-suited to teaching three-dimensional science in ways that resonates with the Next Generation Science Standards. The EPICC VFE resources are especially timely given the reliance on remote instruction during the global pandemic, and provide opportunities to explore, describe and build understanding of basic Earth science concepts. (3) In some cases, the EPICC TCN funding initiated the establishment of several permanent positions dedicated to care of fossil collections. (4) The TCN established much deeper coordination between institutions, especially in standardizing taxonomy and the nomenclature of the rock units (termed Formations) that preserve the fossils, which are the primary vehicle for assigning ages to the fossils they preserved. 

The fossil record provides our only direct window into long-term ecological and evolutionary responses to environmental change. However, the paleontological archive of past change is housed in natural history collections worldwide, but until they are digitally mobilized they remain effectively hidden from the research community. This TCN has thus contributed to NSF's continuing effort to bring the nation's "dark" collections data to light. Data mobilized by the EPICC TCN will allow the research community, as well as the public, to gain a better understanding of the interplay between environmental, ecological, and evolutionary change in the past, the present, and the future.
